Award.AwardTitle: BRAIN EAGER: A novel toolkit for imaging transcription in vivo
Award.AbstractNarration:
Learning requires the conversion of transient experiences into long-lasting changes in neural circuitry. Animal behavior triggers changes in gene expression in small populations of neurons and behaviorally induced genes regulate synapses and neuronal morphology. Yet, it is unclear if changes in gene expression are the cause of behavioral plasticity, or the consequence. This project will develop a new genre of fluorescent reporters that enable the visualization and manipulation of endogenous transcription factors in individual neurons, in real time, and within the brain of behaving animals. During the award period, candidate reporters will be made that recognize six different transcription factors. These reporters will have widespread utility for investigating the molecular mechanisms that support learning in vivo and analysis of populations of neurons that are active during a learning paradigm. The development of these reporters includes ongoing training of undergraduate, graduate, and postgraduate scientists. Student training is optimized with guidance from the CREATE STEM Success Initiative on the UCSD campus.

Inducible transcription factors (ITFs) translate signals that last milliseconds or seconds into changes in cellular function that may persist for hours, days, or longer. This project will develop genetically encoded transcription factor reporters (GETFaRs) that are designed to visualize or manipulate an ITF. GETFaRs are based on molecular scaffolds, engineered through a process of synthetic affinity maturation of camelid nanobodies (Nbs) which bind the endogenous ITF. The Nb protein will be fused to a fluorophore or DNA modifying enzyme, allowing users to visualize or manipulate endogenous transcription factors. A degradation signal (degron) will be incorporated into the Nb near the ITF binding site. Consequently, GETFaRs will be constitutively expressed and rapidly degraded in the cytoplasm. When the ITF is expressed, the GETFaR-ITF interaction will mask the degron, stabilizing the complex. The ITF's nuclear localization signal will translocate the complex into the nucleus, resulting in stabilized GETFaRs that accumulate in the nucleus and stoichiometrically reflect ITF expression. Candidate GETFaRs will be validated in vitro using standard biochemical and imaging techniques and in vivo using two photon imaging of neurons in head fixed mice. Optimal GETFaRs will enable research that 1) monitors or manipulates transcriptional states during learning, 2) studies the emergence of ensembles of co-active neurons within a circuit, 3) probes the dynamics of chromatin and nuclear organization, and 4) analyzes the genome of defined populations of neurons responding to complex, natural stimuli.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mechanisms that govern learning are executed over many time scales and the most enduring forms of plasticity require regulation of the gene expression. Inducible transcription factors support learning at the cellular level by converting brief fluctuations in neuronal activity into long-lasting changes in neuronal function through activity-dependent changes in gene expression. In spite of the importance of this biology, it has not been possible to determine if behaviorally driven changes in transcription are the cause or consequence of learning related changes in neuronal function. This is in large part because we lack the tools necessary to visualize endogenous transcription factors without disrupting their function or regulation.  

This BRAIN EAGER project has made significant progress in developing genetically encoded transcription factor reporters (GETFaRs) designed to visualize inducible transcription factors in real time, and within the brain of behaving animals. Importantly, this novel reporter strategy allows for visualization of endogenous protein without disrupting genomic and mRNA regulatory elements or transcription factor stability and function. GETFaRs are based on molecular scaffolds engineered from camelid nanobody (Nb) libraries to bind specifically to the target protein. The Nb is fused to a fluorescent protein, allowing users to visualize the endogenous transcription factor. Mutations that destabilize the Nb have been incorporated into the Nb backbone allowing GETFaRs to be constitutively expressed and rapidly degraded in the cytoplasm unless the target transcription factor is also expressed in the neuron. Accumulation of the GETFaR-transcription factor complex in the nucleus allows for visual identification of neurons expressing the target ITF in real time.

During the funding period of this grant, we have made several essential advances in the development of this tool. First, we have expanded the capabilities of our Nb discovery technology to include cytosolic protein domains. We have used this improved technology to generate 5 Nbs that recognize protein fragments of the neuron specific inducible transcription factor Npas4. Next, these Nbs were purified and we confirmed that several of them recognize full length Npas4 protein when expressed alone and when co-expressed with a known dimerization partner. Subsequently, we confirmed that purified Nbs can recognize endogenous Npas4 protein induced by neuronal activity in mouse hippocampal neurons.

First generation GETFaRs (Nb-fluorescent protein fusion proteins) have been tested in living cells. When GETFaR1 is expressed, we observe fluorescence exclusively in the cytoplasm. Co-expression with Npas4 results in accumulation of fluorescence in the nucleus, suggesting that the GETFaR binds Npas4 and is brought into the nucleus via this interaction. Finally we have produced a second generation GETFaR (GETFaR2) in which several point mutations have been introduced into the Nb backbone that destabilizes the Nb unless it is bound to the target protein. We observe less cytoplasmic accumulation of GETFaR2 in the absence of Npas4 and persistent nuclear accumulation of the GETFaR when co-expressed with Npas4. Support from NSF BRAIN EAGER has been pivotal in the development of this high-risk, high-reward transcription factor reporter concept. We are continuing to optimize the GETFaR toolkit with the goal of sharing it with the broader community so we and others can better understand the role of dynamic gene regulation in learning and behavior.
